speaker: Neil
text: Hello and happy Christmas! This is 6 Minute English with me, Neil. And joining me today is Sam.

speaker: Sam
text: Hello.

speaker: Neil
text: So, Sam, are you feeling excited about Christmas?

speaker: indulging
text: Of course! Time with friends and family, eating lots, partying, presents – and generally indulging – what’s not to like?

speaker: Indulging
text: Indulging – allowing yourself to have perhaps too much of something you enjoy.  Well, it only happens once a year, Sam. But for those of us who do celebrate Christmas, it comes at a price.

speaker: Sam
text: Yes, well buying all those presents can be expensive.

speaker: Neil
text: Not just that, Sam. I mean it comes at a cost to the environment, as we’ll explain shortly. But let’s start off with a quiz question for you to answer.  In 2010, a Christmas tree in Belgium was awarded the world record for having the most lights on it – but do you how many? Were there…

speaker: Neil
text: What do you think, Sam?

speaker: Sam
text: Well, I don’t think you could fit 194, 673 lights on a Christmas tree, so I’ll say a) 19,672.

speaker: Neil
text: OK. Well, we’ll find out how ‘bright’ you are at the end of the programme! Of course, Christmas trees are the ultimate Christmas decoration. It’s part of the Christmas tradition and millions are bought around the world each year. But what impact do Christmas trees - real and artificial - have on the environment?

speaker: Sam
text: Well before we answer that, let’s hear from some of the BBC Learning English team who  chose to have a real Christmas tree in their home and find out why…

speaker: Sam
text: Phil

speaker: symbolic
text: Well, you've got the smell of it. You've got the look of it. But more importantly, it’s Christmas trees are supposed to be symbolic, aren't they? So the idea of something that stays green all year, so bringing that into your house it, it means something.

speaker: festive
text: I just think a real Christmas tree is more festive and more Christmassy. And it's just the tradition to get a real Christmas tree, that's all.

speaker: sustainable
text: There’s something more beautiful about the nature, the smell, the feel, the look of the tree and I like it to be sustainable. So, as long as I get my tree from a person that promises to grow two or three in its place, then I'm really, really happy.

speaker: symbolic
text: Yes, I agree – you can’t beat having a real Christmas tree. And as Phil said, it’s symbolic – it represents something important – and here a Christmas tree is the symbol of Christmas.

speaker: festive
text: And as Jiaying mentioned, it’s a tradition – something that’s done regularly and has become the expected thing to do – and I’d agree it makes things more festive – a word to describe the joyful feeling you get when celebrating something like Christmas.

speaker: sustainable
text: But of course all these trees are often thrown away, which is wasteful. That's why Roy mentioned his tree being sustainable – which means they can continue to be grown and cut down over a longer period so it’s less harmful to the environment.

speaker: Sam
text: Well, an alternative to a real Christmas tree is a fake or artificial one, which is what Feifei from our team has in her house. What are the reasons why?

speaker: economical
text: We have a plastic Christmas tree, which we've had for about nine years. So it's plastic so you can re-use it every year and it's more economical, and we don't have to keep buying new trees.

speaker: economical
text: So Feifei’s fake tree is made of plastic – so that’s not great for recycling – but the good thing is she uses it year after year which makes it economical – which means it doesn’t cost a lot of money, it’s good value.

speaker: Sam
text: Ah, but even Feifei admits it doesn’t have the smell and feel of a real tree. It’s a dilemma isn’t it, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: Yes – what’s best for us and what’s best for the environment? The BBC’s Reality Check programme found that real trees take about 12 years to grow and as they do, they absorb carbon from the atmosphere and nitrogen from the soil – so a good thing.

speaker: Sam
text: But when it’s chopped down it starts to release emissions back into the atmosphere – especially if you have to transport it to your home. And when Christmas is over, if it ends up in landfill, the tree’s carbon footprint will be higher.

speaker: Neil
text: But its carbon footprint will be lowered if it’s recycled or composted – that’s the process of allowing it to decay and then adding it to the ground to improve soil quality. A fake tree on the other hand is usually imported, and can’t usually be recycled but, as Feifei mentioned, it can be re-used.  But without any type of Christmas tree, where would we put all those lights I mentioned earlier, Sam? I asked you: In 2010, a Christmas tree in Belgium was awarded the world record for having the most lights on it – but did you know how many? What do you say, Sam?

speaker: Sam
text: I think I said 19,672.

speaker: Neil
text: Ooo, not very bright I’m afraid! There were in fact 194, 672!

speaker: Sam
text: Wow – think of the electricity that must have used!

speaker: Neil
text: Indeed. Well let’s enlighten everyone with some of the vocabulary we’ve discussed today.

speaker: indulging
text: OK, well we started talking about indulging – that means allowing yourself to have perhaps too much of something you enjoy.

speaker: symbolicfestive
text: When something is symbolic, it represents something important.  And the word festive describes the joyful feeling you get when celebrating something like Christmas.

speaker: sustainable
text: Like the festive jumper you are wearing today, Neil – very jolly! OK, next we mentioned sustainable – which means the ability to do something over a long period of time without harming the environment.

speaker: Neil
text: Economical describes doing something that doesn’t cost a lot of money, it’s good value.

speaker: composted
text: And when something is composted, it is allowed to decay – and it turns in to compost which can be added back into the soil to improve its quality.

speaker: Neil
text: Thank you, Sam. And that brings us to the end of 6 Minute English for now. It just leaves us to wish you a very happy Christmas. Goodbye.

speaker: Sam
text: Goodbye.
